channel.title: Java: Artichoke Cipher Help

item.title: Java: Artichoke Cipher Help
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

if(VALID_CHARACTERS.indexOf(ch) == -1){
continue;
}

should remove any issues with invalid characters.

public String decode(String s) {
        String t = "";
        for (int i = 0; i < s.length(); i++) {
            char ch = s.charAt(i);
if(VALID_CHARACTERS.indexOf(ch) == -1){
continue;
}
            char shift = keyword.charAt(i % keyword.length());
            int shiftAmount = VALID_CHARACTERS.indexOf(shift);
            int index = VALID_CHARACTERS.indexOf(ch);
            int x= (index - shiftAmount);
            if(x < 0){
               x = VALID_CHARACTERS.length()+x;
            }
            char newChar = VALID_CHARACTERS.charAt(x);
            t += newChar;
        }
        return t;
    }

item.title: Java: Artichoke Cipher Help
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

[quote=“iCreatedHorror, post:16, topic:465462”]I took what you supplied and tried applying it to what I had done, but now I am getting weird results. I get the correct decryption result for the first sentence up until the period which gives me incorrect results.

What I get: [quote]We are using Thomas Jefferson’s Artichoke CIPHER systemzppnmlwZeBuiuuykanrobcsnw
UoCkVhrljnyK.?n’!Wmw?qicSowceoA?wiZf.bqCxjUvNgpl,?cdY.Eed o.UsrgWl.mqdx[/quote]
What I should get: [quote]We are using Thomas Jefferson’s Artichoke CIPHER system
in the first programming assignment. It was not
actually used in the Lewis and Clark expedition.[/quote]

Or, if I make a slight change to make the decode similar (using what Zyle gave me of input = “”; input += word) I get the following.

[quote]
We are using Thomas Jefferson’s Artichoke CIPHER systemWe are using Thomas Jeffe
rson’s Artichoke CIPHER systemin the first programming assignment. It was notWe
are using Thomas Jefferson’s Artichoke CIPHER systemin the first programming as
signment. It was notactually used in the Lewis and Clark expedition.[/quote]

And my current code:

[code=Java]//@author Ryan Malacina

import java.util.Scanner;
import java.io.*;

public class arti {

public static void main (String[] args) throws IOException {
    Scanner one = new Scanner (System.in);

    System.out.print("Please name input file to be processed: ");
    String file = one.next();
    Scanner scan = new Scanner (new File (file));

    System.out.print("Would you like to encode or decode the file ('e' or 'd'): ");
    String choice = one.next();

    System.out.print("Please enter a keyword: ");
    String keyword = one.next();

    final String alphabet = "ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZabcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz ,.!?\'\"";

    if (choice.equals("e")) {
        String input = "";
        while (scan.hasNext()) {
            String word = scan.nextLine();
            input += word;
            for (int i = 0; i < input.length(); i++) {
                char ch = input.charAt(i);
                char shift = keyword.charAt(i % keyword.length());
                int shift_amount = alphabet.indexOf(shift);
                int index = alphabet.indexOf(ch);
                char newChar = alphabet.charAt((index + shift_amount) % alphabet.length());
                System.out.print(newChar);

            }
        }
    }
    else if (choice.equals("d")) {
        while (scan.hasNext()) {
            String word = scan.nextLine();
            for (int i = 0; i < word.length(); i++) {
                char ch = word.charAt(i);
                char shift = keyword.charAt(i % keyword.length());
                int shift_amount = alphabet.indexOf(shift);
                int index = alphabet.indexOf(ch);
                int x = (index - shift_amount);
                if (x < 0) {
                    x = alphabet.length() + x;
                }
                char newChar = alphabet.charAt(x);
                System.out.print(newChar);

            }
        }
    }
}

}[/code][/quote]

for my code are you calling the decode method for each line it does not support linebreaks so you would need to take the line decode then go to the next line.

It was notWe are using Thomas Jefferson's Artichoke CIPHER systemin the first programming as signment. It was notactually used in the Lewis and Clark expedition.

And my current code:

[code=Java]//@author Ryan Malacina

import java.util.Scanner;
import java.io.*;

public class arti {

public static void main (String[] args) throws IOException {
    Scanner one = new Scanner (System.in);

    System.out.print("Please name input file to be processed: ");
    String file = one.next();
    Scanner scan = new Scanner (new File (file));

    System.out.print("Would you like to encode or decode the file ('e' or 'd'): ");
    String choice = one.next();

    System.out.print("Please enter a keyword: ");
    String keyword = one.next();

    final String alphabet = "ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZabcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz ,.!?\'\"";

    if (choice.equals("e")) {
        String input = "";
        while (scan.hasNext()) {
            String word = scan.nextLine();
            input += word;
            for (int i = 0; i < input.length(); i++) {
                char ch = input.charAt(i);
                char shift = keyword.charAt(i % keyword.length());
                int shift_amount = alphabet.indexOf(shift);
                int index = alphabet.indexOf(ch);
                char newChar = alphabet.charAt((index + shift_amount) % alphabet.length());
                System.out.print(newChar);

            }
        }
    }
    else if (choice.equals("d")) {
        while (scan.hasNext()) {
            String word = scan.nextLine();
            for (int i = 0; i < word.length(); i++) {
                char ch = word.charAt(i);
                char shift = keyword.charAt(i % keyword.length());
                int shift_amount = alphabet.indexOf(shift);
                int index = alphabet.indexOf(ch);
                int x = (index - shift_amount);
                if (x < 0) {
                    x = alphabet.length() + x;
                }
                char newChar = alphabet.charAt(x);
                System.out.print(newChar);

            }
        }
    }
}

}[/code]

item.title: Java: Artichoke Cipher Help
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

this seems to encode and decode just fine based on the details you provided, I didn’t bother looking up the actual cipher you might need to.

public class Artichoke {

    private final String keyword;
    private static final String VALID_CHARACTERS = "ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZabcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz ,.!?\'\"";

    public Artichoke(String keyword) {
        this.keyword = keyword;

    }

    public static void main(String[] arg) throws IOException {

        String keyword = "artichoke";
        Artichoke a = new Artichoke(keyword);
        String test = "We are using Thomas Jefferson's Artichoke CIPHER system";
        test = a.encode(test);
        System.out.println("encoded: " + test);
        test = a.decode(test);
        System.out.println("d: " + test);
    }

    public String encode(String s) {
        String t = "";
        for (int i = 0; i < s.length(); i++) {
            char ch = s.charAt(i);
            char shift = keyword.charAt(i % keyword.length());

            int shiftAmount = VALID_CHARACTERS.indexOf(shift);

            int index = VALID_CHARACTERS.indexOf(ch);
            int shifted = (index + shiftAmount) % VALID_CHARACTERS.length();
            char newChar = VALID_CHARACTERS.charAt(shifted);
            t += newChar;
        }
        return t;
    }

    public String decode(String s) {
        String t = "";
        for (int i = 0; i < s.length(); i++) {
            char ch = s.charAt(i);
            char shift = keyword.charAt(i % keyword.length());
            int shiftAmount = VALID_CHARACTERS.indexOf(shift);
            int index = VALID_CHARACTERS.indexOf(ch);
            int x= (index - shiftAmount);
            if(x < 0){
               x = VALID_CHARACTERS.length()+x;
            }
            char newChar = VALID_CHARACTERS.charAt(x);
            t += newChar;
        }
        return t;
    }
}

output:
control: We are using Thomas Jefferson’s Artichoke CIPHER system
encoded: wOmBMEhXPBXSbvHVP?Lk.FAFLUPHXrTVhYWF.RaL"aqsthvDbNYZWBF
decoded: We are using Thomas Jefferson’s Artichoke CIPHER system

Read full topic

item.title: Java: Artichoke Cipher Help
item.dc:creator: @iCreatedHorror Ryan
item.description:
@iCreatedHorror wrote:

Yeah, we have to use Scanner.

The only problem I have now is decoding, I have it so it does either based on choice, but no idea how to decode.

Current code:

[code=Java]//@author Ryan Malacina

import java.util.Scanner;
import java.io.*;

public class Artichoke {
public static void main (String[] args) throws IOException {
Scanner one = new Scanner (System.in);

	System.out.print("Please name input file to be processed: ");
	String file = one.next();
	Scanner scan = new Scanner (new File (file));

	System.out.print("Would you like to encode or decode the file: ");
	String choice = one.next();

	System.out.print("Please enter a keyword: ");
	String keyword = one.next();

	String alphabet = "ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZabcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz ,.!?\'\"";

	if (choice.equals("e")) {
		String input = "";
		while (scan.hasNext()) {
			String word = scan.nextLine();
			input += word;
			for (int i = 0; i < input.length(); i++) {
				char ch = input.charAt(i);
				char shift = keyword.charAt(i % keyword.length());
				int shift_amount = alphabet.indexOf(shift);
				int index = alphabet.indexOf(ch);
				char newChar = alphabet.charAt((index + shift_amount) % alphabet.length());
				System.out.print(newChar);

			}
		}
	}
	else if (choice.equals("d")) {
		String input = "";
		while (scan.hasNext()) {
			String word = scan.nextLine();
			String reverse_alphabet = reverse(alphabet);
			input += word;
			for (int i = 0; i < input.length(); i++) {
				char ch = input.charAt(i);
				char shift = keyword.charAt(i % keyword.length());
				int shift_amount = alphabet.indexOf(shift);
				int index = reverse_alphabet.indexOf(ch);
				char newChar = alphabet.charAt((index + shift_amount) % alphabet.length());
				System.out.print(newChar);

			}
		}
	}
}
public static String reverse (String s) {
	String reverse = "";
	for (int x = 0; x <s.length(); x++)
		reverse = s.charAt(x) + reverse;
	return reverse;
}

}[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: Java: Artichoke Cipher Help
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

Using a Scanner is a pretty shitty method for doing this you would be better off just using runtime arguments? do you have to use Scanner?

public class Artichoke {

    private final String keyword;
    private static final String VALID_CHARACTERS = "ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZabcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz ,.!?\'\"";

    public Artichoke(String keyword) {
        this.keyword = keyword;

    }

    public static void main(String[] arg) throws IOException {

        String keyword = arg[1];
        Artichoke a = new Artichoke(keyword);
        
        //if encoding
        a.encode();
        //else
        a.decode();
    }
    
    public void encode(){
        
    }
    public void decode(){
        
    }
}

item.title: Java: Artichoke Cipher Help
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Using the “one” scanner, after it asks which file you’d like to change, ask again if you want to encipher, or decipher it (e/d), then call a different method.

String action = prompt("Would you like to encipher, or decipher the text? ");
if (action.equals("encipher")) {
    encipher(file);
}
else if (action.equals("decipher")) {
    decipher(file);
}

Read full topic

item.title: Java: Artichoke Cipher Help
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“iCreatedHorror, post:7, topic:465462”]That did help some, this I made it up until [quote]wOmBMEhXPBXSbvHVP?Lk.FAFLUPHXrTVhYWF.RaL"aqsthvDbNYZWBF
SZbOHLdCBbeUVPYRDKKYNDNNd?LcUHIMLQQVkmqOadDPTXaU
.CaX?EVk[/quote] before the outputs began to differ…[/quote]

Actually, it’s all your professor’s fault. Here is the correct string to get the expected output

We are using Thomas Jefferson's Artichoke CIPHER systemin the first programming assignment. It was notactually used in the Lewis and Clark expedition.

As you can see, there is no white character between “system” and “in” as well as “not” and “actually”, and there are 2 spaces after “assignment.”.

If you post this text as the “scan” Scanner’s input instead of a file, you should get the proper outcome. Or do something like this

String input= "";
while (scan.hasNext()) {
    String word = scan.nextLine();
    input += word;
}
for (int i = 0; i < input.length(); i++) {
    char ch = input.charAt(i);
    char shift = keyword.charAt(i % keyword.length());
    int shift_amount = alphabet.indexOf(shift);
    int index = alphabet.indexOf(ch);
    char newChar = alphabet.charAt((index + shift_amount) % alphabet.length());
    System.out.print(newChar);
}

item.title: Java: Artichoke Cipher Help
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Alright, I found the problem. It seems that your instructors input was flawed. CR, LF, CRLF all mess with the results. The way to get the desired output, is that you have to remove the line characters. Try

We are using Thomas Jefferson's Artichoke CIPHER systemin the first programming assignment. It was notactually used in the Lewis and Clark expedition.

As you can see, where your instructor put things on different lines, they really shouldn’t be there at all. Your algorithm works perfectly, just his input and output were wrong.

EDIT: Actually, let me rephrase. The scanner splits based on linefeed characers (CR, LF). However, I think your professor used a StringBuilder, or some other device, and took all 3 lines, combined them into one, and then sent that through the cipher.

EDIT: Actually, I have no idea how your professor got those results.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @iCreatedHorror Ryan
item.description:
@iCreatedHorror wrote:

I have actually seen that already, but it didn’t help me at all

Okay, here is the test message we were given.

We are using Thomas Jefferson's Artichoke CIPHER system in the first programming assignment. It was not actually used in the Lewis and Clark expedition.

Here is the example encoded message using keyword: artichoke

wOmBMEhXPBXSbvHVP?Lk.FAFLUPHXrTVhYWF.RaL"aqsthvDbNYZ[b]WBF[/b] SZbOHLdCBbeUVPYRDKKYNDNNd?LcUHIMLQQVkmqOadDPTXaU .CaX?EVkbPSLGXBXmUCEhvBPSeb.NKdgEKdLVEeSB!SfJJNj

And here is what the last encode looked like for me (they match up until WBF).

wOmBMEhXPBXSbvHVP?Lk.FAFLUPHXrTVhYWF.RaL"aqsthvDbNYZ[b]WBF[/b]BXmUCEhIFKcfbKRVJO WYJIGhDPLSSOHEUWZTzfbRAZdKHd MfV.LSbXNcQEVIUdQAOmt"WPVX XPbeLHUHTOjQ"DPWFHXo

And the last code edit I made:

[code=Java]import java.util.Scanner;
import java.io.*;

public class Artichoke {
public static void main (String[] args) throws IOException {
Scanner one = new Scanner (System.in);

	System.out.print("Please name input file to be processed: ");
	String file = one.next();
	Scanner scan = new Scanner (new File (file));

	System.out.print("Please enter a keyword: ");
	String keyword = one.next();

	String alphabet = "ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZabcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz ,.!?\'\"";

	while (scan.hasNext()) {
		String word = scan.nextLine();
		for (int i = 0; i < word.length(); i++) {
				char ch = word.charAt(i);
				char shift = keyword.charAt(i % keyword.length());
				int shift_amount = alphabet.indexOf(shift);
				int index = alphabet.indexOf(ch);
				char newChar = alphabet.charAt((index + shift_amount) % alphabet.length());
				System.out.print(newChar);
		}
	}
}

}[/code]

item.title: Java: Artichoke Cipher Help
item.dc:creator: @iCreatedHorror Ryan
item.description:
@iCreatedHorror wrote:

This is an assignment I have to do, so I am not looking for an answer given to me. Rather, I was hoping to get some guidance on how to continue.
Note: I am extremely new to Java.

[code=Java]import java.util.Scanner;
import java.io.*;

public class Artichoke {
public static void main (String[] args) throws IOException {
Scanner one = new Scanner (System.in);

	System.out.print("Please name input file to be processed: ");
	String file = one.next();
	Scanner scan = new Scanner (new File (file));

	System.out.print("Please enter a keyword: ");
	String keyword = one.next();

	String alphabet = "ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZabcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz ,.!?\'\"";

	while (scan.hasNext()) {
		String word = scan.nextLine();
		for (int i = 0; i < word.length(); i++) {
				char ch = word.charAt(i);
				char shift = keyword.charAt(i);
				int shift_amount = alphabet.indexOf(shift);
				int index = alphabet.indexOf(ch);
				char newChar = alphabet.charAt((index + shift_amount) % alphabet.length());
				System.out.print(newChar);
		}
	}
}

}[/code]

Okay, so I made progress. It now begins shifting everything properly, but after the keyword length, it errors out. Where should I wrap the keyword length at?

Read full topic
